awd_titl_txt: Engineered nanophotonic Raman amplifiers and lasers
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract title: Engineered nanoscale optical amplifiers and lasers 

Nontechnical:
Silicon photonics is presently among the most active fields of research and development in optical science and technology. Importantly, silicon photonics is compatible with modern electronics technology on which everyday integrated circuit chips for computers and communications are based. Motivating this project, there is a need for useful and economic means for silicon-based light generation for silicon photonics technology. We plan to fill this void by engaging a unique optical resonance effect on nanostructured silicon films to generate light. Thus, we propose to develop new active devices, namely lasers and amplifiers, enabled by this fundamental effect. This can lead to new types of lasers serving as sources for silicon photonic chips as well as amplifiers for enhanced detection of incoming signals carried by light pulses as used in internet data transmission. Integrated photonic systems are expected to increase transmission and processing rates in optical communications. Under the project, we will evaluate the utility of fundamental photonic resonance effects, thus far not applied for this purpose, to enable advanced light generation in silicon. The project provides excellent analytical and experimental experience for graduate students thus supporting the development of the next-generation workforce in photonics technology. If successful, the project will led to innovative light generation and amplification concepts with substantial economic benefits and societal value. 

Technical:
The objective of this research is to design, fabricate and characterize a new class of active nanophotonic guided-mode resonance elements. Specifically, we will investigate Raman amplifiers and lasers enabled by this effect. The research is motivated by the fact that Raman emission can be enhanced to high levels with these high-quality-factor resonance effects that are attainable in nanopatterned silicon films. We present preliminary device designs where the spectral placement of the pump and Raman lasing wavelengths achieves the proper Stokes-Raman shift in silicon. Here, the pump and lasing resonances have large quality factors with corresponding high Raman gain which is dominated by the product of the two factors. These elements will be fashioned as periodic nanostructures in the silicon-on-quartz and the silicon-on-insulator materials systems. We investigate fundamental aspects of the resonance interaction in these devices by computing emission spectra and attendant internal photonic field distributions including local field strengths. The fabricated devices will be characterized by electron-beam and atomic-force microscopy and their detailed spectral properties will be measured. The efficiency of the Stokes-Raman emission, including gain relative to pump, will be quantified relative to device architecture and input pump configuration. This project undertakes fundamental nanophotonic device research that is transformative, if successful, in view of potential applications in silicon photonics.

por.por_cntn:
It is well known that silicon is an inactive material with a band structure prohibiting direct band transitions and laser action. However, silicon is a key optical platform material used in planar light wave circuits with great technological promise and current deployment. Accordingly, the objective of this research is to investigate a new class of active optical devices that could lead to use of silicon for lasers and optical amplifiers. The Raman effect refers to optical excitation of secondary signal photons in a medium by an external light beam. Silicon is amenable to such photon generation and thus to potential lasing at the signal wavelength. The challenge is to come up with a scheme of effective generation of the signal photons. Using an optical resonance effect that can build high field concentration in nanoscale structures, we engage the Raman effect for optical generation with contributions in theoretical analysis and experimental realization and testing. These elements are fashioned as periodic nanostructures in the silicon-on-quartz and the silicon-on-insulator materials systems. We investigate fundamental aspects of the resonance interaction in these devices by computing emission spectra and attendant internal photonic field distributions including local field strengths. The fabricated devices are characterized by electron-beam and atomic-force microscopy and their detailed spectral properties will be measured. The efficiency of the Raman emission, including gain relative to pump, is quantified for various device architectures and input pump configurations. This project undertakes fundamental nanophotonic device research that is transformative, if successful, in view of potential applications in silicon photonics.

Specifically, we observe Raman photon generation under tuning of 220-nm-thick guided-mode resonant periodic lattices with incident pump-beam angle. To enhance device efficiency, we incorporate distributed Bragg reflectors at each side to provide feedback into the resonant grating region. We use a pulsed laser as pump source to raise the efficiency of the pump-signal experiment. We successfully detect Raman signals, albeit at low levels in the nanowatt regime. To precisely match the Raman shift in Si known to be 15.606 THz, we implement controllable resonance split in the 1500-1700 nm wavelength region such that the pump and signal frequencies are separated by approximately this value of frequency. To achieve these results we design initial nanopatterned resonance devices with efficient numerical computational tools. We then fabricate the designed devices and conduct Raman generation experiments. In our demonstration, we show that the Raman signal is detectable upon inputting the right pump wavelength at the correct angle of incidence to realize the proper split between the pump/signal resonant modes. The silicon Raman device is addressable with convenient broadside illumination. In spite of the low initial efficiencies experimentally found in this research, we show that a Raman amplifier is achievable with medium-quality-factor guided-mode resonance device with proper parameter design and setup. We confirm the theoretically predicted Raman shift in silicon with the controllable resonant split modes with the method of incidence-angle tuning under transverse-magnetic polarization. Enhanced design and experimental procedures may lead to improved efficiencies in Raman generation with this method. In summary, the team accomplished the design, fabrication, and spectral qualification a first Si guided-mode resonance structure for Raman generation.
